msDesc.head: Anthology of courtly poetry in English

msItem.note: Modern endleaf with table of contents, headed ‘Some of Chaucer’s Works’, 17th century.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Legend of Good Women
msItem.incipit:
A thousand tymes I haue herde men tell
That ther is ioy in heuen ⁊ peyne in hell
msItem.explicit:
And til she was caughte and fetyrde in pryson
This tale is sey for this conclusion

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Lespistre de Cupide
msItem.rubric:
Incipit littera Cupidinis dei Amoris directa
subditis suis Amatoribus
msItem.incipit:
Cupido vn to whos comaumdement
The gentil kinrede of goddis an hy
msItem.explicit:
The yere of grace ioyfull and iocunde
A thowsande and foure hundred and seconde
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit littera Cupidinis dei amoris
directa subditis suis amatoribus

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Complaynt of the Black Knight
msItem.incipit:
In May when flora the fressh lusty quene
The soyl hath clad in red grene and white
msItem.explicit:
Exiled be that I may noghte attayne
Recure to fynde of myn aduersite

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Anelida and Arcite
msItem.incipit:
Thou ferse god of armes Mars the rede
That in thi firsty contre called Trace
msItem.explicit:
With Iune the temple with a sorofull chere
That shapyn was as ye shall aftyr here

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Complaint of Mars
msItem.incipit:
Gladeth the [corr. ye] louers in the morrow gray
Lo venus risen amonge you rowes rede
msItem.explicit:
That neuyr dide but gentillnes
Kitheth ther fore in her somme kyndesse

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Complaint of Venus
msItem.incipit:
Ther nys none so hieh comforte to my plesaunce
When that I am in eny heuynesse
msItem.explicit:
To folow worde by worde the curiosite
Of gransoun flor of hem that make in fraunse

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Complaint unto Pity
msItem.incipit:
Pitee that I haue soghte so yore Ago
with herte sore and full of bisy peyn
msItem.explicit:
Thus for youre deth I may well wepe and pleyn
With herte sore and full of bisye peyn

msItem.title: A Lover’s Plaint
msItem.incipit:
As ofte as syghes ben in herte trewe
And cristall teres on dolefull chekes trill
msItem.explicit:
Sith I am wounded with youre yen tweyn
lete me no lengur sighen for youre sake

msItem.title: A Complaint for Lack of Sight
msItem.incipit:
For lak of sighte grete cause haue I to pleyne
longe absence so sore me werreyth
msItem.explicit:
Disdeyneth not but of godely hede
Haueth ther on mercy and pite

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Temple of Glass
msItem.incipit:
For thouȝt constrenit and greuous heuines
ffor pensifhede and for heiȝ distres
msItem.explicit:
I mene þat benygne & goodli of hir face
Nou go þi way & put þe in hir grace

msItem.author: John Clanvowe (?)
msItem.title: The Cuckoo and the Nightingale or The Book of Cupid
msItem.incipit:
The god of loue a benedicite
Hov myȝti and hou gret a lord is he
msItem.explicit:
Terme of life love haþ withhold me
So loude þat I with þat song a woke

msItem.title: Envoy to Alison
msItem.incipit:
O lewde booke with þi foole rudnes
Siþ þou hast noþir beaute ne eloquence
msItem.explicit:
Of grace I biseke alegge be youre writyng
Non of al good siþ Ȝe be best lyving

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Book of the Duchess
msItem.incipit:
I haue gret wondir be þis liȝte
hou þat I lyve for day ne nyȝt
msItem.explicit:
best at a non
The my sweuyn now hit is don

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Parliament of Fowls
msItem.incipit:
The lif so short the craft so long to lerne
The assay so hard so sharp the conqueryng
msItem.explicit:
That I shal meete som thyng for to fare
The bette and thus to rede I nyl not spare
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit tractatus de Congregacione
volucrum die Sancti valentini

supportDesc.foliation: i–iv, 1–135 in modern pencil; each recto also features a nineteenth-century pagination in ink (now crossed out).
supportDesc.collation: 1–38, 48+1 (singleton leaf added as fol. 33), 5–98, 102, 11–138, 142, 15–168, 172, 188, 194–1 (3rd leaf cancelled), 204–2 (3rd and 4th leaves cancelled). The manuscript is comprised of 4 booklets: fols. 1r–75v, 76r–101v, 102r–119v, and 120r–132v (with a break in production between fols. 33 and 34). The last quire of each booklet is shorter than the preceding ones to align with the end of the texts. Catchwords only appear at the end of quires 5–9 (fols. 41v, 49v, 57v, 65v, 73v), and 16 (fol. 117v), in the bottom right corner of the page and underlined in ink, in the hand of Scribe B.
supportDesc.condition: Mould damage throughout, first and last first and last folios present more worn than other pages.

layoutDesc.layout: Each page is fully ruled for one column of 34–38 lines, ruled space 177–182 110 , the height of the ruling space varies slightly between booklets, but the width remains consistent across the codex. Pricking trimmed.
Ruled variously in hard-point (fols. 100r–101v), pencil (fols. 76r–99v, 120r–131v), crayon (110r–119v), and ink (fols. 1r–75v, 102r–109v)

handDesc.handNote: Three hands (following Ramela Robinson, 1980) identified as A, B, and C from the order in which they appear. Scribe A, fols. 1r–33v and 120r–131v: mixed hand of principally Anglicana Formata with Secretary graphs
Scribe B, fols. 34r–75v and 110r–119v, a typical mid-fifteenth-century Secretary hand.
Scribe C fols. 76r–109v: mixed hand of principally Anglicana Formata with Secretary graphs

decoDesc.decoNote: Decorated initial, four lines high and decorated with acanthus leaves on a gold ground (fol. 1r).
Border in the left margin, consisting of a narrow double band of gold, blue, and pink with acanthus leaves and spray work (fol. 1r).
The beginning of each text is marked with blue Lombardic capitols with red infillings and flourishes (fol. 28v incomplete, missing red flourish).
Item 1 (fol. 1r–40v) features red and blue flourished initials that introduce each legend. Divisions in Items 4 (fol. 59v–65r), 5 (fol. 65r–69v), and 10 (fol. 76r–97r) also display such initials.

physDesc.additions: A seventeenth century hand (identified as Archbishop William Sancroft by Robinson, 1980) added headings to Items 3–7, 11, 13, and 14 (fols. 48v, 59v, 62v, 65r, 67v, 69v, 71r, 97r, 102r, and 120r). The same hand added a table of contents (fol. iii) titled ‘Some of Chaucer’s Works’. A sixteenth-century hand(s) has added five irregular lines of verse after the end of Item 14.

history.origin:
15th century, middle
England MS. Tanner 346 belongs to E.P. Hammond’s ‘Oxford Group’ (1908), a collection of three manuscripts now in the Bodleian Library: MS. Tanner 346, MS. Fairfax 16, and MS. Bodley 638. These manuscripts are strikingly similar in content and are thought to derive from a singular lost exemplar. M.C. Seymour (1993) classifies Tanner as a ‘closely linked sub-group’ in the context of Chaucer’s Legend of Good Women. From the lack of coordination between the scribes, Robinson (1980) suggests MS. Tanner 346 is not the product of a commercial bookshop. There is no evidence to suggest for whom the manuscript was produced.
history.provenance: Late fifteenth or early sixteenth century names: Anne (margin, fol. 70r), Only ʒovrss AN (margin, fol. 81r), AH (margin, fol. 80v), Philip Joisilyn (fol. 131r), JGraystock (fol. 131r), John Greystoke (fol. 132v), Richard Justice (margin, fol. 131r). Greystoke is perhaps identifiable as Sir John Greystoke (who died in 1501), the second son of Ralph, Lord Greystoke.

Pen trial, fol. 132v reads Swanimotum tentum apud lufeld xij die octobris anno regni regis henrici octaui xxxij, alluding to a swanimote – a local court responsible for the judicial and administrative regulation of a forest (Robinson 1980) – apparently at the (former) Benedictine priory of Luffield, in the Forest of Whittlebury. Another sixteenth-century hand has written below sanguis rana pulex (the beginning of a mnemonic on the ten plagues)
William Sancroft, 1617–1693: W. Sancroft (fol. 1r). Robinson suggests it is his hand that supplies the table of contents and headings (1980). His books were sold on his death to:
history.acquisition: Bequeathed by him to the Bodleian in 1735.

recordHist.source:
Description by Charlotte Ross, December 2021. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (A. Hackman, Catalogi codicum manuscriptorum Bibliothecæ Bodleianæ pars quarta codices viri admodum reverendi Thomæ Tanneri, S.T.P., episcopi Asaphensis, complectens, Quarto Catalogues IV, repr. 1966, with corrections, from the ed. of 1860). Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 90
Quarto Catalogue, Cols. 749–750

listBibl.bibl: Michael Seymour, The manuscripts of Chaucer's Legend of good women, Scriptorium, 47/1 (1993), 73-90, https://doi.org/10.3406/scrip.1993.1659
Manuscript Tanner 346: a facsimile, ed. Pamela Robinson (1980)
Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library Oxford, III (1973), no. 1039
